Why not access all of the various functionality of a service by 
specifying different ACCEPT values on the request?  So, if I want the 
service's response in XML for programmatic access, I would specify 
ACCEPT: text/xml.  Or, if I want the UI for user access, I would 
specify text/html.  To get the schema, I could specify 
application/xsd+xml.  To get the interface def, I could specify 
application/kinda-like-wsdl-for-rest+xml.  Sure, some necessary MIME 
types don't exist, but isn't that a fault of MIME and not HTTP?  
After all, if XML can get its own MIME type even though its really 
just text, why stop there?

Okay, so we'd end up with billions of MIME types for everyone's 
different schemas.  But since XSD is so core, it really should have 
its own MIME type.  Perhaps one more new MIME type is needed: 
application/metadata+xml, which when requested would return an index 
of all various metadata of the service, such as scaler values like 
author and version, and links (different URLs) to complex metadata, 
such as reviews of the service.  Of course, these different URLs 
could themselves be services, which can be accessed programatically 
(via ACCEPT: text/xml) or by a user (via ACCEPT: text/html).  The 
reviews could even have reviews.

> "S. Alexander Jacobson" wrote:

> > > Consider a movie.  Is it worth seeing?  If Gene Siskel gives it 
a
> > 
> > I think we are mixing two very separate concepts
> > of metadata.
> 
> I believe that you are missing my point.  Let me quote David Jacobs:
> 
> "Metadata about a web service goes beyond a WSDL file, XML Schemas 
and a
> tmodel description.
> 
> A web service may have
> * a WSDL file
> * an HTML description
> * XML schema's it returns and accepts
> * a DAML-S description
> * a reliability rating
> * a usefulness rating
> * how it can be integrated with other services
> 
> Furthermore, while a service provider will often produce a lot of 
> service metadata to facilitate its use, they cannot be seen as
> objective 
> parties when contributing metadata to be used in matchmaking (i.e., 
is 
> this the service I need).  Clearly there is a role for third 
parties to
> add their own metadata about a service in the form of ratings and 
new 
> metadata formats which might increase the service's usefulness for 
a 
> population segment."
> 
> My point is that a HOW metadata document is just a small part of the
> metadata that you will associate with web service.  Further, even 
of the
> HOW metadata there will be many, many different formats - XHTML, 
WSDL,
> RDF, DAML-S, OWL, etc.  To top it off, all of the many metadata
> documents will be distributed across the Web [just like all of the 
Web
> sites that link to your Web page are distributed across the Web].
> 
> Bottom line: for a Web service there will be many (many) metadata
> documents, spread across the Web.  The key is to provide a "general
> mechanism" for associating a metadata document with a web service. 
> That's what Meta-Location buys you.  /Roger
